deliberation: Formulaic prophetic introduction וַיְהִי דְבַר־יְהוָה אֵלַי לֵאמֹר portrays the divine word as something that comes to the prophet. This is a conventional but still figurative personification/metaphor of "word" as a moving, acting entity. No other imagery present.

instances.english_text: The word of GOD came to me:
ground: initiative, directed movement toward the prophet, personal address
transfer of something from sender to receiver
instances.explanation: God’s communication is depicted as a concrete ‘word’ that comes to Ezekiel, personifying and metaphorically embodying revelation as a moving entity that approaches and addresses him.

deliberation: Verse sets up a watchman scenario. Within the scenario, most elements are literal in their own frame, but "sword" for an invading force is a standard metonymy. The appointment of a נֶצֹפֶה (lookout) is literal here, though it will be applied metaphorically to Ezekiel in v.7.

instances.english_text: When I bring the sword against a country
ground: a sword is an instrument of killing and war, so it stands for armed conflict and its destructive force
instrument representing its user and act
metonymic association of tool and action
instances.explanation: The ‘sword’ stands metonymically for an invading army or war. God does not literally bring a single sword upon a land; the weapon represents the larger reality of military judgment.

deliberation: Continues the watchman illustration. Again, the scene is literally conceivable, but "sword" coming upon the land functions as metonymy for an advancing army or warfare.

instances.english_text: Suppose he sees the sword advancing against the country
ground: the sword is the characteristic weapon of battle, so it easily stands for war and its destructive onset
posture: vivid depiction to ground later moral point
instances.explanation: The ‘sword’ here again stands metonymically for the hostile army or war that is approaching the land, not for a literal single weapon moving across the countryside.

deliberation: Two primary figurative expressions: (1) the sword that ‘comes and takes’ a person—personification plus metonymy for invading forces; (2) the idiom ‘his blood will be on his head’ for personal guilt/responsibility.

instances.english_text: and the sword comes and dispatches him / takes him
target: killing of the individual by invading forces
death in war as divine judgment
vehicle: a sword that comes and takes someone
ground: the sword is the immediate instrument of death in battle and can be pictured as an active agent that ‘takes’ life
agency of the weapon standing for the killers
instances.explanation: The sword is both metonymic (standing for attackers) and personified as an agent that ‘comes’ and ‘takes’ someone’s life, vividly depicting death by war.

instances.english_text: his blood shall be on his own head
target: personal guilt and liability for one’s own death
ground: blood symbolizes life taken and guilt incurred; locating it ‘on the head’ pictures responsibility resting visibly and personally on the individual
instances.explanation: The idiom depicts guilt for one’s own death as ‘blood’ resting on one’s head, a metaphor for bearing full responsibility for the outcome.

deliberation: Reiterates v.4. One idiom repeats (‘his blood shall be upon himself’), and another expression ‘he has delivered his soul’ uses נֶפֶשׁ (soul) for ‘life’ and conceptualizes rescue as delivering the soul. Both are figurative.

instances.english_text: their bloodguilt shall be upon themselves
target: self-incurred guilt for one’s own death
ground: blood as symbol of life taken and guilt; the idea of it being ‘upon’ the person pictures their responsibility as a burden that clings to them
instances.explanation: The idiom uses ‘blood’ upon the person as a metaphor for the guilt and responsibility they carry for their own death.

instances.english_text: had they taken the warning, they would have saved their life (lit. ‘delivered his soul’)
vehicle: precious inner self rescued from danger
ground: נֶפֶשׁ stands metonymically for the whole person’s life; to ‘deliver’ it is to rescue from threat, picturing survival as escape from captivity or danger
life conceptualized as something that can be carried off or saved
instances.explanation: Life is spoken of as a ‘soul’ that can be delivered or rescued, using נֶפֶשׁ metonymically for the person’s life and the metaphor of escape from danger for survival.

deliberation: Two main figurative features: (1) recurring ‘sword’ imagery as metonymy for invaders; (2) idiom ‘I will require his blood from the hand of the watchman,’ where ‘requiring blood’ and ‘hand’ stand for holding someone accountable.

instances.english_text: I will demand a reckoning for their blood from the lookout (lit. ‘from the hand of the watchman I will seek his blood’)
target: God’s holding the watchman morally accountable
vehicle: seeking someone’s blood from their hand
hand as locus of power and responsibility
ground: blood symbolizes guilty death; the ‘hand’ symbolizes control and responsibility. To ‘seek blood from the hand’ pictures God demanding payment or accounting from the one who held responsibility
posture: severe warning to the prophet as watchman
instances.explanation: The idiom portrays God as demanding ‘blood’ (guilt for another’s death) from the ‘hand’ of the negligent watchman, metaphorically expressing divine accountability and retribution.

instances.english_text: and the sword comes and destroys one of them (lit. ‘takes a life from them’)
target: killing of individuals by invading forces
ground: the sword is the means of killing and so stands for the warriors; its ‘taking’ a life pictures the lethal effect of the invasion
violence leading to loss of life
posture: negative evaluation of failure to warn
instances.explanation: The sword is a metonym for the attacking forces, described as coming and ‘taking’ a life, emphasizing the deadly consequence of unheeded danger.

deliberation: Here the earlier literal watchman scenario is explicitly mapped onto Ezekiel’s prophetic role, so ‘watchman’ is now metaphorical. ‘House of Israel’ is a standard metonymy for the people as a whole. Both are figurative.

instances.english_text: I have appointed you a lookout for the House of Israel
vehicle: a watchman posted over a city or people
ground: both a watchman and a prophet must be vigilant, perceive approaching danger, and warn others, bearing responsibility for their response
instances.explanation: Ezekiel’s prophetic office is compared to a city watchman’s role, making his task of warning Israel about impending judgment vivid through the metaphor of vigilant surveillance.

instances.english_text: for the House of Israel
ground: a ‘house’ can denote a family or lineage; here it stands for the entire people descended from Israel, emphasizing corporate identity
instances.explanation: ‘House’ is used metonymically for the entire people of Israel, a conventional way of designating the nation as a single extended household.

deliberation: Main figurative element is the idiom ‘I will demand his blood from your hand’ (requiring blood from Ezekiel), expressing accountability. Other phrases are straightforward.

instances.english_text: while from you I will demand a reckoning for their blood (lit. ‘I will seek his blood from your hand’)
target: Ezekiel’s responsibility for failing to warn the wicked
vehicle: seeking someone’s blood from another’s hand
blood as a due that can be demanded
hand as symbol of agency and responsibility
ground: blood represents wrongful death; the ‘hand’ represents control and action. God’s seeking blood ‘from the hand’ pictures him exacting payment or holding someone answerable for another’s death
instances.explanation: The idiom portrays God as demanding the ‘blood’ (guilt for the wicked’s death) from Ezekiel’s ‘hand,’ a vivid metaphor for divine exaction of accountability from the prophet.

deliberation: Key figurative expression: ‘you will have saved your life’ (lit. ‘you have delivered your soul’), using נֶפֶשׁ for life and the metaphor of delivering/rescuing the soul.

instances.english_text: while you will have saved your life (lit. ‘you have delivered your soul’)
target: Ezekiel’s own preservation from divine judgment
vehicle: rescuing an inner self from danger
removing a precious entity from peril
ground: נֶפֶשׁ stands for the person’s life; to ‘deliver’ it evokes saving someone from captivity, danger, or death. Ezekiel’s obedience ‘rescues’ his own life from judgment
life conceptualized as something that can be taken or saved
instances.explanation: Life is described as a ‘soul’ that can be delivered, using metonymy for life and the metaphor of rescue from danger to describe Ezekiel’s escape from guilt.

deliberation: Two related figurative expressions: (1) ‘our transgressions and sins are upon us’ portrays sins as a burden resting on people; (2) ‘in them we are wasting away’ uses imagery of bodily decay for inner spiritual/psychological disintegration under guilt.

instances.english_text: Our transgressions and our sins [are] upon us
target: the oppressive effect of guilt on the exiles
vehicle: a weight or load resting on a person
ground: a physical burden weighs upon and oppresses; guilt and sin create a similar felt heaviness and inescapable pressure
psychological oppression conceptualized as physical load
instances.explanation: Israel’s sins are pictured as a heavy load resting upon them, a metaphor for the oppressive, inescapable nature of their guilt.

instances.english_text: and we are wasting away because of them (lit. ‘in them we are rotting away’)
target: their progressive spiritual and emotional deterioration under judgment and guilt
vehicle: physical decay of flesh or material
ground: physical rot is slow, destructive, and irreversible; the people’s experience of judgment and guilt feels like a slow internal decay
sickness/decay imagery applied to spiritual/moral state
instances.explanation: The community’s inner collapse under sin and exile is likened to a body rotting away, turning their spiritual despondency into vivid decay imagery.

deliberation: Key figurative cluster is the path metaphor: ‘turn back’ from ‘your evil ways’ conceptualizes moral conduct as a way/road and repentance as turning around. ‘House of Israel’ and oath formula are conventional.

instances.english_text: Turn back, turn back from your evil ways
target: Israel’s patterns of behavior and moral choices
vehicle: ‘ways’ as roads or paths; ‘turning back’ as changing direction on a path
ground: a course of life resembles traveling along a path; to change one’s conduct is like turning around and choosing a different route
posture: strongly negative evaluation of current conduct, positive appeal to change
instances.explanation: Israel’s behavior is depicted as walking along ‘ways,’ and repentance is portrayed as turning around on those roads, a standard path metaphor for moral transformation.

deliberation: Dominant figurative expression is ‘the wickedness of the wicked will not cause him to stumble when he turns from his wickedness’—stumbling as a metaphor for suffering ruin/failure because of sin. Other elements are conceptual but fairly literal.

instances.hebrew_text: וְרִשְׁעַ֤ת הָֽרָשָׁע֙ לֹא־יִכָּ֣שֶׁל בָּ֔הּ בְּי֖וֹם שׁוּב֣וֹ מֵֽרִשְׁע֑וֹ
instances.english_text: nor shall the wickedness of the wicked cause them to stumble when they turn back from their wickedness
target: suffering ruin or downfall because of past sin
vehicle: tripping and falling on a path
ground: to stumble is to lose stability and fall; moral ruin and judgment are like tripping, losing one’s footing, and collapsing
posture: positive evaluation of turning from sin
instances.explanation: Past wickedness is pictured as something that could cause a person to ‘stumble’—a metaphor for ruin or harm—but God assures that when they truly turn back, it will not trip them up.

deliberation: Verse states a moral principle about the righteous who turn to iniquity. Expressions like ‘none of his righteous deeds shall be remembered’ personify God as remembering/forgetting, but this is standard covenantal-legal language rather than vivid imagery; no strong distinct metaphor or idiom beyond that.

Statement about a wicked person who turns and does justice and righteousness. Uses standard legal-moral vocabulary; no clear metaphor, simile, or idiom beyond the already established ‘you shall die’ formula.
Key figurative expression is ‘he walked in the statutes of life’—conduct conceptualized as walking on a path defined by God’s ‘statutes of life.’ Rest of the verse is legal and literal.

instances.english_text: follow the laws of life (lit. ‘walked in the statutes of life’)
target: living in obedience to God’s life-giving commands
ground: a way of life is like a route one walks; God’s statutes provide the path that leads to life, so obedience is like walking within those life-giving tracks
instances.explanation: Obedience is depicted as ‘walking’ in God’s ‘statutes of life,’ using the path metaphor for life conduct and presenting the commands as a roadway that leads to life.

deliberation: Main figurative expression is ‘none of the sins…shall be remembered to him,’ conceptualizing forgiveness as God’s ‘forgetting’ sins. This is anthropomorphic and metaphorical for not holding sins against someone.

instances.hebrew_text: כׇּל־חַטֹּאתָו֙ אֲשֶׁ֣ר חָטָ֔א לֹ֥א תִזָּכַ֖רְנָה ל֑וֹ
instances.english_text: None of the sins that they committed shall be remembered against them
target: God’s act of forgiving and no longer holding sins against a person
vehicle: failure to call something to mind or record it
ground: to remember is to keep something on record and act in light of it; not remembering pictures God as erasing or refusing to consult a record of sin
posture: positive evaluation of just and righteous behavior
instances.explanation: Divine forgiveness is depicted as God’s ‘not remembering’ sins, a metaphor for wiping them from the record so that they no longer count against the person.

deliberation: Uses ‘way’ (דֶרֶךְ) for God’s manner of dealing and Israel’s manner of life—standard path metaphor for habitual conduct/strategy. The people say ‘the way of the Lord is not right/fair,’ contrasted with ‘their way is not right.’

instances.hebrew_text: לֹ֥א יִתָּכֵ֖ן דֶּ֣רֶךְ אֲדֹנָ֑י וְהֵ֖מָּה דַּרְכָּ֥ם לֹא־יִתָּכֵֽן
instances.english_text: ‘The Sovereign’s way is unfair.’ But it is their way that is unfair!
target: God’s pattern of judgment and mercy; Israel’s patterns of conduct
divine and human ways of acting
vehicle: a ‘way’ or road along which one travels
route with direction and quality (straight/right vs. crooked/unfit)
ground: a course of action can be likened to a road: it has direction, can be straight or crooked, suitable or unsuitable; the judgment of ‘not right’ plays on this path imagery
journey metaphor for moral practice and policy
instances.explanation: Both God’s judicial practice and Israel’s behavior are described as ‘ways,’ using the path metaphor to frame the dispute over whose course is truly ‘right’ or ‘fitting.’

deliberation: Again uses the path metaphor: ‘when the righteous turns from his righteousness and does iniquity’—turning from righteousness as changing direction on a path. The death result is literal punishment.

instances.english_text: When someone righteous turns away from their righteous deeds
target: abandoning a previously righteous pattern of life
ground: leaving a course of righteous living is like turning off a straight path to another direction
directional movement as image of change
posture: warning of the danger of apostasy
negative evaluation of turning from righteousness
instances.explanation: Moral defection is conceptualized as physically turning away from a path of righteousness, continuing the path imagery of moral life.

deliberation: Mirror of v.18. Uses ‘turning back from wickedness’ and living ‘by’ just and right deeds. Path metaphor is primary: turning from one path to another. ‘Live by them’ is conceptual but essentially literal promise.

instances.english_text: And when someone wicked turns back from wickedness
target: repentance of a formerly wicked person
ground: changing from wicked to just behavior is like turning around and going the opposite way on a road
posture: hopeful invitation and validation of repentance
positive evaluation of change toward justice
instances.explanation: Repentance from wickedness is portrayed as turning back on a path, dramatizing moral change as a reversal of direction.

deliberation: Again uses ‘way’ (דֶרֶךְ) for God’s and Israel’s behavior, and ‘each according to his ways I will judge you’—judgment according to one’s path. This is the same path metaphor for conduct and policy.

instances.english_text: I will judge each one of you according to your own ways
target: individual patterns of life and behavior
vehicle: ‘ways’ as roads or paths people follow
ground: a person’s behavior over time resembles a path they take; judgment ‘according to his ways’ is like evaluating which route he chose and where it led
instances.explanation: God’s judgment is said to be ‘according to your ways,’ using the path metaphor to describe a person’s life-course as the road by which they are assessed.

deliberation: The phrase ‘the city has been struck’ (הֻכְּתָה הָעִיר) uses the city as metonymy for its community and ‘struck’ as battle language. The rest is narrative and literal.

instances.english_text: The city has fallen (lit. ‘the city has been struck’)
vehicle: physical blow delivered to an object
ground: to ‘strike’ is to wound or defeat; the city stands for its people and defenses, so being struck pictures the community’s military defeat
instances.explanation: The city is used metonymically for its population and defenses, and described as ‘struck,’ a martial image conveying Jerusalem’s conquest.

deliberation: Two figurative expressions: (1) ‘the hand of YHWH was upon me’—metaphor for overpowering divine influence; (2) ‘he opened my mouth’ and ‘I was no longer mute’—metaphorical for enabling prophetic speech.

instances.english_text: Now GOD’s hand had come upon me
target: prophetic inspiration and overpowering divine influence on Ezekiel
vehicle: physical grasp or pressure by a powerful hand
ground: a hand upon someone controls, directs, and can be heavy or compelling; divine influence likewise seizes, directs, and empowers the prophet
instances.explanation: God’s powerful influence is depicted as his ‘hand’ resting on Ezekiel, a conventional metaphor for being seized and controlled by divine power.

instances.hebrew_text: וַיִּפְתַּ֣ח אֶת־פִּ֔י ... וַיִּפָּ֣תַח פִּ֔י וְלֹ֥א נֶאֱלַ֖מְתִּי עוֹד
instances.english_text: opening my mouth ... my mouth was opened and I was no longer speechless
target: restoration of Ezekiel’s prophetic speech and commission
capacity and authorization to speak God’s word
vehicle: opening a mouth that was closed
ground: a closed mouth cannot speak; opening it allows speech. Ezekiel’s prior restriction and now renewed ability are pictured as physical mouth-closure and opening
instances.explanation: Ezekiel’s divinely imposed muteness and its end are portrayed as his mouth being shut and then opened, a concrete metaphor for being unable and then authorized to speak on God’s behalf.

deliberation: Same prophetic formula as v.1: ‘the word of YHWH came to me.’ Again personifies the divine word as approaching the prophet.

instances.english_text: The word of GOD came to me:
vehicle: a ‘word’ that comes to a person
ground: communication is conceptualized as something that travels from sender to recipient; the ‘word’ is treated as an agent that approaches and speaks
instances.explanation: As in v.1, God’s message is personified as a ‘word’ that comes to Ezekiel, a metaphor for the arrival of revelation.

deliberation: Argument about Abraham and the current inhabitants of the ruins. ‘Ruins’ are literal devastated sites; references to inheriting the land are covenantal but not figurative per se in this verse. No distinct rhetorical figure beyond conventional language.

Two notable figurative elements: (1) idiom ‘you lift up your eyes to your idols’ for turning one’s attention/dependence toward them; (2) rhetorical-ironical question at the end: after listing bloody sins, ‘and you [expect to] possess the land?’—dramatic irony/sarcasm.

instances.english_text: you raise your eyes to your fetishes (idols)
target: directing devotion, trust, and worship toward idols
vehicle: lifting up the eyes toward something
looking up in expectation or reverence
ground: where one looks, especially upward, indicates attention, desire, and reverence; turning the gaze to idols pictures giving them one’s worship and trust
orientation of gaze as sign of devotion
instances.explanation: The idiom ‘lift up the eyes to’ portrays idolatrous devotion as directing an upward, reverent gaze toward idols, a metaphor for turning one’s trust and worship toward them.

instances.english_text: yet you expect to possess the land!
target: their presumptuous expectation of security and blessing despite sin
vehicle: rhetorical question following a list of crimes
ground: stating their expectation after enumerating disqualifying sins creates an irony: the outcome they anticipate is obviously incongruous with their behavior
posture: biting rebuke and exposure of folly
instances.explanation: After listing bloodshed and idolatry, the closing question ‘and the land you will possess?’ functions ironically—mocking their assumption that they can secure the land while flagrantly violating God’s commands.

deliberation: Key idiom: ‘you have stood upon your sword’—likely meaning relying on violence/armed power. The repeated ending ‘and you [expect to] possess the land?’ continues the irony of v.25 as a separate rhetorical device.

instances.english_text: You men have relied on your sword (lit. ‘you have stood upon your sword’)
target: trusting in violent power for security
ground: to stand upon one’s sword evokes reliance and constant readiness to use violence; their security is pictured as literally founded on the weapon
metonymic use of sword for violent power
instances.explanation: Their dependence on violence is depicted by the idiom ‘you have stood upon your sword,’ a metaphorical way of saying that their footing and stance are based on armed might.

instances.english_text: yet you expect to possess the land!
target: their expectation of inheriting the land while committing abominations
vehicle: rhetorical question following charges of abomination and adultery
ground: the gap between their immoral behavior and their expectation of blessing creates an ironic tension; the form implies the outcome is absurd
posture: derisive exposure of their false hopes
instances.explanation: As in v.25, the climactic question ‘and you will possess the land?’ is an ironic device that ridicules their confidence in possessing the land despite their abhorrent conduct.

deliberation: Describes three groups and their deaths—by sword, beasts, pestilence. These are standard judgment motifs and may be literal outcomes; there is no clear additional figurative turn beyond established prophetic stock phrases.

Two primary figurative expressions: (1) ‘the pride of its strength shall cease’ personifies the land’s ‘proud glory’ as something that can be stilled; (2) ‘the mountains of Israel shall be desolate, with none passing through’ likely uses hyperbole (‘no one passing’) to intensify the picture of desertedness.

instances.english_text: and its proud glory shall cease (lit. ‘the pride of its strength shall rest/come to an end’)
target: Israel’s former power, security, and splendor in the land
visible magnificence of the land and people
vehicle: a proud entity coming to a halt
ground: national greatness is likened to a proud, exalted state; its ‘resting’ or being stilled pictures humiliation and cessation of that self-exalting power
instances.explanation: The ‘pride of its strength’ personifies Israel’s former power and glory as a proud thing that can be brought to rest, portraying the coming end of national self-exaltation.

instances.english_text: and the mountains of Israel shall be desolate, with none passing through
target: extreme depopulation and abandonment of the land
total disruption of normal life and travel
vehicle: mountains so desolate that no one passes through them at all
ground: a landscape without a single passerby is an intensified picture of desolation and abandonment, exaggerating the emptiness to underscore total devastation
instances.explanation: Saying that no one at all passes through the mountains is likely hyperbolic, using an extreme picture of emptiness to stress how thoroughly the land will be laid waste.

deliberation: Formula ‘they shall know that I am YHWH’ is covenantal but not strongly figurative; ‘make the land a desolate waste’ continues literal-judgment language from v.28. No additional clear rhetorical figures emerge here beyond standard terminology.

People ‘speak about you by the walls and at the doors’—literal clandestine conversation. Figurative element: ‘what word has gone out from YHWH’—the ‘word’ depicted as something that goes out from God, like a dispatched message.

instances.english_text: what word has issued from GOD (lit. ‘what is the word going out from YHWH’)
vehicle: a ‘word’ that goes out from someone
ground: a spoken message proceeds from a speaker; describing it as ‘going out’ personifies the word as a thing or agent leaving God, emphasizing its origin and dynamic movement into the world
posture: curious but superficial interest by the people
instances.explanation: God’s message is personified as a ‘word’ that goes out from him, picturing revelation as a dispatched entity leaving its divine source.

deliberation: Two figurative phrases: (1) ‘they are doing loves/lusts with their mouth’—speech portrayed as erotic/affective output, a kind of sensuous talk; (2) ‘their heart goes after their gain’—heart as seat of desire and ‘going after’ as metaphorical pursuit.

instances.english_text: For they produce nothing but lust with their mouths (lit. ‘for loves/lusts with their mouth they are doing’)
target: their insincere, sensuous, self-gratifying speech in response to Ezekiel
vehicle: erotic/affectionate acts associated with the mouth
ground: their speech is not obedient response but self-indulgent verbal enjoyment, likened to performing acts of lust or love with the mouth
instances.explanation: Their response to Ezekiel’s message is described as ‘doing loves with their mouth,’ portraying their talk as sensual, self-pleasing verbal output rather than genuine obedience.

instances.english_text: and their hearts pursue nothing but gain (lit. ‘after their gain their heart goes’)
vehicle: an inner organ moving in pursuit
pursuing something as a follower or hunter
ground: the ‘heart’ stands metonymically for the inner self; its ‘going after’ gain pictures desire and will chasing profit as one would pursue a target
movement toward an object of desire
instances.explanation: Their inner self (‘heart’) is portrayed as actively going after material gain, a metaphor for their greedy pursuit of profit that overrides any sincere response to God’s word.

deliberation: Core figure is an explicit simile: Ezekiel is ‘like’ a singer of love/bawdy songs with a beautiful voice and skillful playing. This compares his prophetic message’s reception to entertainment music that people enjoy but don’t obey.

instances.hebrew_text: וְהִנְּךָ֤ לָהֶם֙ כְּשִׁ֣יר עֲגָבִ֔ים יְפֵ֥ה ק֖וֹל וּמֵטִ֣ב נַגֵּ֑ן
instances.english_text: To them you are just a singer of bawdy songs, who has a sweet voice and plays skillfully (lit. ‘and behold, you are to them like a song of loves, of beautiful voice and skillful playing’)
target: how the people perceive and treat Ezekiel’s prophetic ministry
their reception of God’s word as mere entertainment
the prophet’s function in their eyes
vehicle: a performer of a ‘song of loves’ with beautiful voice and skillful music
ground: both the prophet and an entertainer speak/sing to an audience; here the audience enjoys the sound but does not act on the content, as if Ezekiel were merely a pleasing love-song performer
artistic performance imagery for prophecy reception
posture: negative evaluation of their superficial listening
instances.explanation: Ezekiel’s role in the people’s eyes is compared, via simile, to that of a singer of love songs whose beautiful performance is enjoyed as entertainment rather than heeded as a serious, life-directing message.

deliberation: Speaks of the coming of what has been prophesied and the people’s recognition of a prophet in their midst. The language is straightforward; no additional clear figurative devices beyond previously established judgment concepts.
